sub_topic: Using the unit circle to find trigonometric values
message_1: Find the exact value of sin(π/6) using the unit circle.
message_2:
The unit circle is a circle with a radius of 1 centered at the origin (0,0) of the coordinate plane. To find the exact value of sin(π/6), we need to find the y-coordinate of the point where the terminal side of the angle π/6 intersects the unit circle.

The angle π/6 is equivalent to 30 degrees. In a 30-60-90 right triangle, the ratio of the side lengths is 1:√3:2. If we consider a 30-60-90 triangle with hypotenuse 2, the side opposite the 30-degree angle (which is the y-coordinate on the unit circle) is half the length of the hypotenuse.

So, in this case, the y-coordinate (which represents the sine value) is half of the hypotenuse of the 30-60-90 triangle:

sin(π/6) = sin(30°) = 1/2

Therefore, the exact value of sin(π/6) is 1/2.
